diseases.name: Parvo Virus
diseases.description: Highly contagious viral disease in dogs causing gastrointestinal issues and immune suppression.
diseases.transmission: Spreads via fecal-oral route, contaminated surfaces like shoes, clothes, and fur.
diseases.treatment: No direct cure. Treatment involves IV fluids, anti-nausea meds, antibiotics for secondary infections.
diseases.mortality: High if untreated, but survival improves with care.

diseases.name: Canine Distemper
diseases.description: A highly contagious viral disease in dogs that affects the respiratory, digestive, and nervous systems, weakening the immune system.
diseases.transmission: Airborne droplets from coughing/sneezing, shared food bowls, contaminated surfaces, infected mothers to unborn puppies.
diseases.common_in: Unvaccinated dogs, especially puppies under four months old. Also spreads through infected wildlife.
diagnosis: Lab tests like PCR or antibody detection
diseases.treatment: Supportive care: IV fluids, antibiotics, symptom management, isolation.
diseases.mortality: Around 50%, survivors often have lasting nervous system damage.

diseases.name: Leptospirosis
diseases.description: A bacterial infection caused by Leptospira, found in soil and water.
diseases.transmission: Contact with infected urine, contaminated water, or soil.
diseases.common_in: Dogs of all ages and breeds, especially in rainy areas.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics, IV fluids, medications, nutritional support. Severe cases may need oxygen therapy or dialysis.
diseases.prevention: Vaccination, avoiding contaminated water sources and wildlife.

diseases.name: Aural Hematoma
diseases.description: A localized blood collection within the ear flap, causing swelling and discomfort.
symptoms: Crusting or debris in the ear
diseases.causes: Frequent head shaking or scratching due to infections, allergies, trauma, or clotting disorders.
diseases.common_in: Dogs with floppy ears, including Cocker Spaniels, Basset Hounds, and Golden Retrievers.
diseases.treatment: Surgical drainage or repeated draining with steroid injections. Underlying conditions must be treated.
diseases.complications: If untreated, can lead to chronic inflammation, ear deformities, and persistent discomfort.

diseases.name: Lyme Disease
diseases.description: Bacterial infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through blacklegged ticks.
diseases.risk: Can mimic other tick-borne diseases, making diagnosis challenging.

diseases.name: Gingivitis
diseases.description: Inflammation of the gums, the earliest and reversible stage of periodontal disease.
diseases.causes: Bacterial infection from plaque buildup, poor oral hygiene.
diseases.treatment: Professional dental cleaning and regular home care.

diseases.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diseases.description: Chronic condition where the body can't properly use sugar due to insulin issues.
diseases.risk_factors: Common in middle-aged dogs, older cats, small dog breeds.
diseases.complications: Higher infection risk, liver fat buildup, vision loss, nerve damage.
diseases.treatment: Insulin injections, high-fiber diet, regular check-ups.

diseases.name: Laryngeal Paralysis
diseases.description: A condition where the airway doesnâ€™t open properly, making breathing difficult.
diseases.treatment: Mild cases: Tranquilizers, corticosteroids. Severe cases: Surgery.
diseases.prognosis: Good with treatment, but requires lifelong care.

diseases.name: Canine Hepatitis
diseases.description: A serious liver disease caused by Adenovirus, leading to liver damage.
diseases.transmission: Direct contact with infected dogs, contaminated food, water, objects, or airborne droplets.
diseases.treatment: Medications, IV fluids, liver-friendly diet, antibiotics if needed.

diseases.name: Tetanus
diseases.description: A rare but serious bacterial disease in dogs caused by Clostridium tetani toxin, affecting the nervous system and leading to muscle rigidity and spasms.
diseases.transmission: Bacteria enter through deep wounds or punctures contaminated with soil, dust, or feces containing C. tetani spores. Spores become active in low-oxygen environments and produce the neurotoxin tetanospasmin.
diseases.common_in: Unvaccinated dogs with untreated deep wounds, especially in rural or outdoor environments.
diseases.breeds_at_risk: No breed-specific predisposition, but working and outdoor dogs may be more exposed to contaminated environments.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical examination, history of recent wounds, characteristic symptoms. No reliable lab test, but blood work, urinalysis, ECG, and X-rays may help assess complications.
diseases.treatment: No direct cure. Early administration of tetanus antitoxin may help. Treatment includes IV fluids, antibiotics (Penicillin G, metronidazole), wound debridement, muscle relaxants, and intensive nursing care in a quiet, dark environment to reduce spasms.
diseases.prognosis: Survival rates range from 50-90%. Localized tetanus has a better prognosis, while generalized tetanus with complications like pneumonia worsens outcomes. Recovery can take weeks.
diseases.prevention: No vaccine recommended for dogs. Prompt wound care, thorough cleaning, and antibiotic treatment can reduce the risk. Immediate veterinary attention is crucial if muscle rigidity develops after an injury.

diseases.name: Gastric Dilatation-Volvulus (GDV)
diseases.description: A rapidly progressive and life-threatening condition in dogs where the stomach dilates and may rotate, leading to severe complications requiring immediate medical attention.
diseases.transmission: Not contagious. Caused by multiple factors, including rapid ingestion of large meals, deep chest conformation, single daily feeding, stress, and genetic predisposition.
diseases.common_in: Large and giant breed dogs, especially those with deep chests. Older dogs, those fed one large meal per day, and dogs with a family history of GDV are at higher risk.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs, abdominal x-rays, blood work (CBC, serum chemistry, electrolytes), urinalysis, ECG for cardiac arrhythmias, blood gas analysis to assess respiratory compromise.
diseases.treatment: Requires immediate medical stabilization, including IV fluids, oxygen therapy, gastric decompression via stomach tube or needle, and surgical intervention. Surgery includes de-rotation of the stomach, removal of non-viable stomach tissue if necessary, and gastropexy to prevent recurrence.
diseases.prognosis: Mortality rate is around 15%. Higher risk of death if clinical signs persist for more than 6 hours, cardiac arrhythmias occur before surgery, or if part of the stomach or spleen must be removed.
diseases.prevention: Feeding multiple small meals per day, avoiding rapid eating, reducing stress, and prophylactic gastropexy in at-risk breeds or dogs with a family history of GDV.

diseases.name: Megaesophagus
diseases.description: Progressive disorder in which the esophagus becomes dilated and loses motility, leading to difficulty in moving food to the stomach.
diseases.transmission: Not contagious; can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired due to neuromuscular diseases, obstructions, or other medical conditions.
diseases.common_in: More frequent in dogs than cats. Breeds at high risk include German Shepherds, Great Danes, Irish Setters, Newfoundlands, Wire Haired Fox Terriers, Miniature Schnauzers, Shar-Peis, Greyhounds, and Labrador Retrievers. Siamese cats may also be predisposed.
diseases.diagnosis: X-rays (esophageal dilation), contrast studies (barium swallow), blood tests to rule out underlying causes, fluoroscopy, endoscopy, nerve-muscle biopsies.
diseases.treatment: No direct cure. Management includes upright feeding (Bailey Chair), high-calorie diet (liquid or 'meatball' consistency), treating underlying conditions, and preventing aspiration pneumonia with antibiotics and careful feeding techniques.

diseases.name: Lick Granuloma (Acral Lick Dermatitis)
diseases.description: Chronic skin condition in dogs caused by obsessive licking, leading to self-trauma, inflammation, and infection.
diseases.transmission: Not contagious; develops due to physical or psychological factors like allergies, joint pain, stress, or anxiety.
diseases.common_in: Middle-aged to older, large breed dogs.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical examination, X-rays (for arthritis), skin tests (for infections), allergy testing, neurological and behavioral assessments.
diseases.prognosis: Can be chronic and challenging to treat but manageable with long-term care and commitment.

diseases.name: Xylitol Toxicity in Dogs
diseases.description: A severe and potentially fatal condition in dogs caused by ingestion of xylitol, a sugar substitute found in many human products.
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of xylitol-containing products such as sugar-free gum, candies, baked goods, peanut butter, toothpaste, medications, and personal care items.
diseases.common_in: Dogs of all breeds, particularly those with access to human food or personal care products.
diseases.diagnosis: Based on history of ingestion, clinical signs, and blood tests to check for hypoglycemia and liver enzyme elevation.
diseases.treatment: Immediate veterinary care is critical. Includes IV fluids, glucose supplementation, liver protectants, and medications to manage symptoms.
diseases.prognosis: Good if treated early before symptoms worsen. Delayed treatment can lead to severe hypoglycemia, liver failure, and death.
